awd_titl_txt: Dual Cooperative Catalysis by Group 4 Metals and Cr
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, & Mechanisms B Program of the National Science Foundation, the research team at Columbia University led by Professor Jack R. Norton will explore fundamental issues in organometallic chemistry and develop green catalysis for the synthesis of value-added chemicals. They will use inexpensive and abundant Group IV metals such as titanium, in combination with other transition metals, to cooperatively activate and transform dihydrogen gas—one of the cleanest and most economical chemical sources. This project involves a mixture of inorganic, organometallic, and organic chemistry, and therefore offers an interdisciplinary environment for training early career scientists. Students in the Norton research group are encouraged to interact with both academic and industrial scientists, to prepare themselves for careers in either professional sector.

The project will address four important issues in organometallic and organic chemistry: (1) it will develop more efficient bimetallic catalysts for the preparation of a class of primary alcohols (those with unbranched structures) that are of special importance; (2) it will explore the replacement of the cyclopentadienyl ligands in the Ti part of these catalysts with less expensive and more readily available alkoxy ligands; (3) it will try to apply these bimetallic catalysts in radical cyclizations for the construction of polycyclic scaffolds in natural products; (4) it will determine whether the proton cleavage of Group IV metal-carbon bonds in O– and N–containing complexes involves a proton relay mechanism. This project involves a mixture of inorganic, organometallic, and organic chemistry, and therefore offers an interdisciplinary environment for training early career scientists.  The PI has an outstanding record of training early career scientists, and is engaged in standing up a web site that offers examples of kinetics problems the group has utilized through the years as a pedagogical tool for the community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Metal-hydride-catalyzed hydrogen atom transfer (MHAT) has proven to be a robust and powerful strategy for forming carbon-carbon and carbon-heteroatom bonds through radical intermediates. Metal hydrides, particularly those based on abundant first-row transition metals, exhibit high reactivity due to their relatively weak M-H bonds. The aim of this NSF-funded project was to explore the applications of hydrogen atom transfer through dual metal catalysis. As part of this initiative, we have designed several novel reactions to achieve heterocyclic ring opening, desaturation, cyclization, and olefin functionalization.

Specific achievements include the development of a Ti-catalyzed reaction for the reduction of epoxides to anti-Markovnikov alcohols via 1,4-hydride transfer, the pioneering synthesis of pyrrolidine derivatives from enamides using V-promoted methods, and the demonstration of remote β,γ- or γ,δ-desaturation of amides through Fe/Cr-H cooperative catalysis or Fe/Co dual metal catalysis. Additionally, we have outlined an efficient method for synthesizing alkylated N-acyl cyanamides employing a nitrogen-umpolung strategy. Building on our findings under the NSF award, we continue to develop new synthetic transformations initiated by HAT, aiming to construct high-value molecules and provide tools for other synthetic chemists in drug development processes.

Beyond research, this project has served as an effective training and outreach platform, involving three undergraduate students, three master's students, five graduate students, and over twenty high school students. Our commitment extends to making science accessible to the New York community. For example, our graduate student participates actively in the New York Academy of Sciences After-School STEM Mentoring Program. Through this program, she engages students from public schools in underserved neighborhoods, deepening their understanding of STEM disciplines and developing appropriate science curricula for primary and middle schools. Over the past two years, she has mentored high school students from Frank McCourt High School, guiding them in independent research projects focused on sustainability, the environment, and alternative energy sources.

Furthermore, members of our group have contributed to Girls Science Day at Columbia, dedicated to inspiring young women's interest in science. They organize hands-on STEM experiments for middle-school girls, encouraging their exploration of scientific concepts in fields like computer science and chemistry. Our efforts aim to dismantle gender barriers and foster an inclusive environment where girls feel empowered to pursue scientific interests. Additionally, one of our group members participated in the STEM Starters program, which introduces middle school students to STEM fields through monthly workshops and science labs outside the traditional classroom setting. This initiative aims to ignite a passion for science among local middle school students, bridging Columbia University with the broader community through meaningful engagement.

 


Last Modified: 07/03/2024
Modified by: Jack R Norton
